definitions: A punctuation mark (;) indicating a pause, typically between two main clauses, that is more pronounced than that indicated by a comma but less pronounced than that indicated by a period.
A punctuation mark used to separate items in a list, especially when the items themselves contain commas.
examples: Use a semicolon to connect two closely related independent clauses.
The list included cities; states; and countries.
He often misused the semicolon in his essays.
